posts.name: Katya
posts.cooked:
Hey all! Message from my team’s programming captain about some issues we’ve been dealing with for a bit:

Hiya, we use sparkflex vortex with YAGSL . We are having an issue that’s taken about a week from us. We have never used YAGSL before and thus we cloned the 2025 example. But after dialing in our settings for our swerve system we found that the wheels would not settle on the position that the system has set as the target. 3 of the 4 motors go to the 135 degree position when we move the controller stick left or right (with the drive direction inverting for right). When trying to move forward the wheels stay around 30 degrees off forward. 1 of the motors is offset from the position requested of it while the encoder is correctly tuned. Here are some steps we have taken: • The encoders are properly tuned and they show the correct location for the wheels. • We tried tuning PID and we believe that’s not the issue as the behavior is not reminiscent of PID issues.

We’re happy to provide more information (pics, videos, etc.) and are grateful for your help. Thanks!
We can’t help well until we get a video with advantagescope or elastic, and cdode

posts.name: Katya
posts.cooked:
We got a video and a WPILOG. https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1n0qCLNVrPuYOCCdpj3S8ufaaVM7j-Hfh This is the link to our github (We are currently use the branch “MasterDevTest”)

GitHub - FirewallRobotics/A-Bot-2025-2 Contribute to FirewallRobotics/A-Bot-2025-2 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to FirewallRobotics/A-Bot-2025-2 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Let me know if you need more info!

What modules and gearing are you using?

Also can you count the teeth on your pinion gears? Your steering pinion gear should be 12T if it is a Thrift Swerve Module

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
I’m a mentor here.   It’s Thriftyswerve, with the Thrifty Analog Encoder and Venom/Sparkflex motor controllers (both drive and steer).  Pigeon 2.

After going back ONLY to the YAGSL -example code (adding our motors/encoder/IMU to the config file), we discovered an oddity:    If we point the wheels forward and turn on the robot, the wheels steer correctly.  If we point them off to the side and turn on the robot, the robot assumes that this direction is the new “forward” (might be different for every wheel).   Seems to imply that the offset for our absolute encoder isn’t being used and everything is just going off relative positions.

There is a fallback when the absolute encoder cant be used yet to use the offset of the relative encoder. Are you using Thrifty Absolute Encoders?

Also VENOMS?! I never thought i would see the day!!!

Send a pic plz and a PR for the new motor wrapper!

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Not Venoms.   They’re Vortexes.   The rev motors that have the motor controller built in.  (  All V words are adjacent in my brain and I sometimes mix them up.  Be glad I didn’t call them Vampires.)

It is the thrifty absolute encoder.

:sad: Can you send a photo of how you connect the thrifty encoders to the roboRIO for verification? I am hoping this is an easy fix.

Can you also send a link to your CURRENT code?

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Code is here: GitHub - FirewallRobotics/A-Bot-2025-2 at 40c6db7e06feb58ac1e14f66217ab2a7314c8402

Unfortunately, when I got to the robot tonight (it’s in my garage), I discovered that our temporary electronics board had been disconnected from all the swerve modules.   I do know that we were able to read values in order to find the offsets, and we did double-check that (a) the correct modules were connected to the correct analog inputs, and (b) they weren’t connected in reverse.

Just reread this and i think this is an 8 steps problem.

Also can you update to 2025.3.1-beta3 image 1320×2868 534 KB

suggested_topics.title: Locked Rotor Data for CTR Minion
suggested_topics.excerpt: Has anyone seen Locked Rotor Data for the CTR Minion? Knowing what is safe would help greatly. Until official values are available, would using the Neo 550 values be reasonable?

suggested_topics.title: Kraken X60 Failures
suggested_topics.excerpt: Has anyone seen this type of failure on Kraken x60 motors? The rotating part seems to rub on the wires until the insulation is cut through and the wires short out.
